awd_titl_txt: Creating Technical Scholars: A Model for Structured Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
This ATE project enables Eastern Shore Community College to establish the Creating Technical Scholars (CTS) program, which will bring together local high-tech employers, school districts, and four-year institutions to create flexible career pathways beginning in high school and potentially culminating in an associate's and/or bachelor's degree.  This project addresses a weakness in short-term training programs that may prepare individuals for immediate employment, but do not serve students in earning more advanced degrees required for promotion to higher paying jobs within their chosen trade. As a result of this project, students enrolling in trade programs will have tracks available in a Technical Studies associate's degree to efficiently utilize classes already taken and to progress in clearly laid out pathways towards a degree that is customized. A key emphasis of the project is also on recruiting and retaining students who are typically underrepresented in STEM fields. Since the demographics and employer needs of Eastern Shore Community College align closely with those of other rural community colleges, and since the service area conditions of high poverty and unemployment and low levels of educational attainment are common, the pathways created may serve as a model to impact other regions nationally. 

More specifically, the Creating Technical Scholars (CTS) program will create a seamless transition from secondary through post-secondary education to employment in STEM fields and high-tech positions. The model will include stacked credentials, internships, business/industry-designed curriculum, capstone experiences, and articulation agreements with baccalaureate institutions.  The model will increase student success and boost economic development by increasing the number of workers and improving skill level, while meeting the needs of employers. There are four overarching project objectives which include: (1) To design dual enrollment technical tracks in career and technical education programs, allowing students to earn simultaneous high school and college credit as well as complete a career studies certificate in technical and occupational programs (Industrial Tech., Computer Tech., HVAC, and Electronics) during their junior and senior years. (2) To create a Technical Studies associates degree with tracks in Cybersecurity, Industrial Technology, HVAC, Welding, and Electricity as a means of targeting dual enrollment and certificate completion student in order to establish a pathway to upper division studies. (3) To establish articulation agreements with regional four-year institutions in technical study fields so as to optimize the educational pathway of students who want to transition from a 2-year degree to a 4-year degree. (4) To devise career tracks for students to begin careers in technical study fields after receiving a post-secondary credential.  In this regard, the project leverages local business/industry partners, who will work with Eastern Shore Community College to provide work-based learning experiences, including internships, job-shadowing, discipline-related conferences, and skills competitions, in high-demand technical fields.

por.por_cntn:
The project Creating Technical Scholars: A Model for Structured pathways (CTS) provided a solution to a question that is too frequently asked; "Should I go to college or learn a trade?" The project was created from the premise that the choice could be to do both. CTS created stackable credentials within four tracks: Electricity, HVAC-R, Industrial Technology and Welding. Each track features multiple entry and multiple exit points and encourages reentry and continuing education. Instruction can begin with expanded high school dual enrollment classes partnering with the two public school systems in Eastern Shore Community College's service area. Each track offers an entry level credential: a career studies certificate (CSC).  Every class included in the CSC's may be applied to academic certificates or intermediate level CSC's.

A cornerstone achievement of the CTS project was the development and implementation of an Associate of Applied Science in Technical Studies. Every class included in each of the four tracks may be applied to the Technical Studies AAS.

The Technical Studies AAS was developed with the guidance of an advisory group meeting in a series of workshops and meetings. The initial workshop was led by an external professional facilitator. The makeup of the advisory group included representatives from employers in the service area, the two public school systems and the two closest upper division universities. From the inception, the AAS was designed with dual purpose. It was designed to deliver the skills needed by employers but it was also designed to articulate efficiently with university partners and provide graduates with the option of further study and advanced academic credentials.

The CTS project provided assistance in the transition from school to work through Resume' assistance, mock interviews, stipends for internships, workplace tours and mentor shadowing. Participant support paid the cost of EPA licensures for HVAC-R students and OSHA 10 hour cards and other enabling costs in the programs feeding the Technical Studies degree. These were efforts that would help a program completer be more competitive in the job market. Over the funded period of the project, 31 students were placed in 52 internships with 14 host sites. 52% of placements have turned into full-time permanent employment positions. 5 Female interns are in trades programs and 60% are minorities (two did not disclose race/ethnicity). All participants had either completed a GED or were public school graduates from the ESCC service area of Accomack and Northampton Counties. 17% were GED recipients.

The CTS project has been an agent for institutional change and a catalyst for system-wide change. To better serve employed trades professionals, the CTS project team promoted updates to the college's prior learning policies, procedures and forms. These changes were adopted institutionally. The changes made it more convenient for students to earn college credits for relevant experiences in the workplace. The updated policies recognized Standardized Examinations, Industry Certifications, On-the-Job Training or work experience or an option to challenge course content through a faculty prepared examination.

During the project period, the Virginia Community College System implemented policy changes that positively impacted future development and success of Technical Studies programs. One change simplified the approval process by making the addition of Technical Studies tracks a local decision only requiring the approval of the Chief Academic Officer. Another policy change guaranteed that any Technical Studies program would qualify for a specific state funding stream (G3).

CTS supported the professional development of faculty teaching in the trade programs. Although, the pandemic stay-at-home order presented significant challenges and delays, over the duration of the project, faculty attended: ATE Conference, High Impact Technology Exchange Conference, National Career Pathways Conference and some trade specific shows and training. Project findings and activities were disseminated where possible.

Every item, on the timeline submitted as a part of the project proposal, was addressed. Some were delayed, yet most were accomplished. Over 75% of the project advisory board indicated that they would like to continue to serve on an advisory board for the Technical Studies AAS.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/25/2022
Modified by: John H Floyd
